comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Crosby: Nellie Fassett (Mrs. John Sherwin) Crosby, president of the NWDL Cullop: Nettie Goodwin (Mrs. William A.) Cullop, congressman's wife, DAR regent, Vincennes (Indiana) chapter "Sayers": Mrs. Steven Beckwith Ayres of NY, another congressman's wife, also active with the NWDL Linthicum: Helen A. (Mrs. John Charles) Linthicum of Baltimore, another congressman's wife Henry: Louine Childers Tyler (Mrs. Robert Lee) Henry (b. 1866) of Texas, another congressman's wife Hopkins: Labeled "Miss Hopkins," can't find more on her.

comment.author: 35014516@N03
comment._content: Thanks! We'll add these full names to the source data and reload the description.

comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: Oh ... Miss Hopkins... she wasn't married to a congressman, so perhaps she was, at the time, 'lesser known' to the caption writer ;)   She was identified in a different WNDL photo here. Grace Porter Hopkins (b.1873), daughter of John Warren and Helen M. (Stoddard) Porter, married Randolph D. Hopkins in1893. Like the other five women in the above photograph, she was a founding Director of the Woman's National Democratic League, Inc., in 1912. She was Vice President, D.C. Federation of Woman's Clubs; Vice President, Woman's National Press Association; Secretary Woman's National Democratic League and Officer, Louisa Adams Chapter D.A.R. Hopkins was co-editor of the popular The Economy Administration Cook Book in 1913 -- a collection of recipes that were delicious and submitted by the Wives of Senators, Congressmen and other notable people. It was put together to give a collection of wholesome economical recipes, as stated in the book “The subject of the high cost of living is one that is uppermost in the minds of the people of the present day universally.” Mrs. Hopkins was also a Washington correspondent for a syndicate of newspapers. [1] [2] [3]

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pixelwrangler] Oh good!  I love when all the members of a group photo can be accounted for.  Wonderful to have this last piece.
